items.name: Java
items.info: The one I most often work with. I like it for its consistency and stability.

items.name: Kotlin
items.info: My language of choice for backedn

items.name: TypeScript
items.info: Good way to make ES more friendly to programmers

items.name: JavaScript
items.info: I like to work with it as it is very flexible, sometimes wired and funny.

items.name: Groovy
items.info: Although I used it mainly in spock tests (and some gradle configs) I really like the power it gives over the typical java.

items.name: Python
items.info: I've most often use it to script something or write an extension.

items.name: PHP
items.info: Sometimes the easiest and fastest to use, even I don't like its inconsistency and style.

items.name: SQL
items.info: Powerful and useful - I used it for many years already.

items.name: Spring
items.info: I started using it 15 years ago and I'm happy it evolves all the time. Heavily used the security module.

items.name: Jdbi
items.info: Another standard which is well defined and simple. Almost alwayse used it with Hibernate, just once with google BigData

items.name: JPA
items.info: Another standard which is well defined and simple. Almost alwayse used it with Hibernate, just once with google BigData

items.name: Hibernate
items.info: I've spent many years with it and I could for example configure level 2 cache or add interceptors to monitor entity changes

items.name: MySql
items.info: I used it in many projects already but I don't feel like a dba for it

items.name: pact.io
items.info: Not only backend related but I think fits here best

items.name: MongoDb
items.info: I've used it in my hobby project (including MapReduce functionality) and one commercial but never used it in real production, so I'm not aware of it's weakness. But I still really liked it.

items.name: React
items.info: I really like the idea of creating own 'tags' and the way the library works

items.name: Next.js
items.info: Used to create this CV

items.name: Redux
items.info: Simple and powerful, although I still don't like the switch and constants for actions

items.name: Html
items.info: Understanding the DOM structure and what DOM is, used HTML for about 15 years now

items.name: CSS
items.info: I know how to use it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

items.name: Tailwindcss
items.info: I'm not sure yet I like this approach, very comfortable on one hand on other I can see potential problems with it

items.name: Sass
items.info: An eye opener for CSS issues, very simple and very useful same time.

items.name: ReactNative
items.info: I've used it many years ago and it would be my choice for any next mobile application

items.name: Dagger
items.info: Small and sharp, I also use it in small java web apps - for which Spring IOC is to heavy

items.name: Butterknife
items.info: Pretty useful and helps removes a lot of boilerplate code

items.name: Firebase
items.info: Only started with services it provides. I researched OCR, messaging and configuration modules

items.name: GreenDAO
items.info: I've chosen it over ORMLite solution, it's faster and simpler to use

items.name: Retrofit
items.info: Natural choice for android rest client, I've not write to many client methods yet

items.name: EventBus
items.info: It eased events sending and threads handling a lot

items.name: analytical mind
items.info: Always want to understand whole systems and how they work technically and in real live, often helping BA with fixing analysis gaps. Really like to find sources of difficult bugs.

items.name: creative
items.info: I like to suggest solutions and I like to create (both software and 'real' things)

items.name: fast learner
items.info: I really like to learn and doing it almost all the time in my free time

items.name: mentor
items.info: Always happy to introduce new people to the project, team or technology

items.name: relish a challenge
items.info: Bigger challenge, bigger fun!

items.name: good sense of humour
items.info: It's much better to work in happy place with happy people!
